title: Kenya: Wangusi Defends Draft Dominance Regulations
text:
Kenya: Team Kenya Vow to Bag Overall Title At Regional Tournament 
"The views from the consultive process were considered and incorporated in the draft regulations that were then sent to the Ministry of ICT for their review and onward transmission to the Attorney general's chambers," he said in a statement. "The authority is in receipt of the letter from the ministry of ICT forwarding the regulations to the Attorney General's office." 
CA further said that firms can only be declared as dominant in a specific market, after a study is conducted in partnership with CAK Folowing their memorandum of understing in April. 
"Dominance is not tied to a specific firm, it is delineated to specific economic markets," Wangusi said, adding that market share is only a presumption of dominance. 
The DG gave the example of economic markets being mobile voice, fixed voice, voice termination, SMS and money transfer services within the telecommunications sector. 
"To determine the competitiveness, each of these markets are analysed separately. In view of this, any firm could be dominant in any one of these markets," Wangusi said. 
Wangusi added that declaration of dominance is not meant to punish any firm, but check against any anticompetitive action that could pose a risk to the market as a whole. 
"The proposed Fair Competition and Equality of Treatment Regulations seek to identify dominant players in the various economic markets, and apply appropriate and proportionate preventative measures to forestall the possibility of abuse of dominance," Wangusi said. 
He added that the regulations on market dominance which are still being formulated, are not specific to the telecommunication market, but the ICT industry as a whole. 
Regulators including the CA are, under the Statutory Instruments Act of 2013, required to seek approval from National Assembly's committee on delegated legislation before they enforce new rules, orders, regulations, directions and guidelines. Kenya
